newsitem.title: MEXICO: FORECAST - Penoles '96 EPS seen weaker.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - Penoles '96 EPS seen weaker.

text.p: The world's largest refined silver producer Industrias Penoles took a double blow in 1996, as world gold and silver prices weakened and the peso remained steady, analysts said.
"Silver and gold prices started to decline in December which has squeezed margins," ING Barings analyst Sebastian Barry-Taylor said.
In a survey of five analysts, average estimated earnings for 1996 were 2.53 per share, compared with 2.99 the previous year.
A combination of a slipping peso and higher gold and silver prices boosted earnings for 1995. Penoles benefits from a weak peso as most of the company's transactions are completed in dollars.
Although 1996 ended with a whimper as gold and silver prices weakened, plans to boost production probably helped the company's earnings recover some of the lost ground.
"The fourth quarter saw better sales volume but was also affected by low metal prices," BBV-Probursa analyst Jose Buendia.

Gold and silver prices fell to $357 and $4.66 respectively per ounce, compared with 1996 averages of $387 for gold and $5.20 for silver. Many brokerages lowered their earnings estimates for Penoles in light of the squeeze on precious metal prices.
The company's health in 1997 will depend on the company's expansion programs and silver and gold prices, analysts agreed. Penoles is also working to reduce its vulnerability
The company's sodium sulfate and other chemicals output is expected to boom through greater extraction, Salomon Brothers analyst Mauricio Reveco wrote in a recent report.
Geographic and mining diversification toward more value-added products will also hedge dependence on metal prices, he said.

"We expect Penoles' treatment and production capacity expansions, along with greater operating efficiency, will fuel rapid growth in earnings at a compound annual real growth rate of 18.3 percent in 1996-2001 period," the report said.
Reveco said long-term contracts and more direct contact with clients is part of a larger effort to protect against sharp drops in metal prices.
